name: SCAMPER
description: 7 thought-sparking questions to transform existing products/ideas

steps.question: What component can be substituted?
steps.example: Uber: substitute traditional taxis with private cars

steps.question: What can be combined?
steps.example: Grab: ride + food + payment in one app

steps.question: What can be adapted from another industry?
steps.example: Tinder: swipe from mobile UX → dating

steps.question: Can it be used for something else?
steps.example: Slack: game chat tool → business communication

steps.question: What can be eliminated?
steps.example: Notion: eliminate multiple apps → all-in-one workspace

steps.question: Can the process be reversed?
steps.example: Priceline: customer names price → hotel accepts

best_for: Finding new angles for old markets

name: Lean Canvas
description: 1-page business model for startups, focused on problem-solution fit

sections.name: Customer Segments
sections.prompt: Who are the early adopters? Be specific.

sections.name: Unique Value Proposition
sections.prompt: Single, clear, compelling message that turns an unknowing visitor into an interested prospect.

sections.name: Solution
sections.prompt: Top 3 features to solve the top 3 problems?

sections.name: Channels
sections.prompt: Path to customers? (SEO, Ads, Referral, Content...)

sections.name: Revenue Streams
sections.prompt: Revenue model + Life Time Value + Revenue + Gross Margin

sections.name: Cost Structure
sections.prompt: Customer Acquisition Cost, Distribution Cost, Hosting, People, etc.

sections.name: Key Metrics
sections.prompt: Key activities you measure (DAU, MRR, Retention...)

sections.name: Unfair Advantage
sections.prompt: Something that cannot be easily copied or bought.

name: 5W1H Analysis
description: Basic framework to analyze an idea comprehensively

questions.question: What is the product? What problem does it solve?
Who uses it? Who pays? Who decides?
Why do they need it? Why now? Why you?
When do they use it? How often?
Where is it used? Online/Offline? Mobile/Desktop?
How does it work? What tech? How to monetize?

name: Blue Ocean Strategy
description: Find a new market (blue ocean) instead of competing in a crowded one (red ocean)

canvas.question: Which factors that the industry takes for granted should be eliminated?
canvas.example: Southwest Airlines: eliminate meals, assigned seating

canvas.question: Which factors should be reduced well below the industry's standard?
canvas.example: IKEA: reduce staff service, assembly service

canvas.question: Which factors should be raised well above the industry's standard?
canvas.example: Dyson: raise design and technology standards

canvas.question: Which factors should be created that the industry has never offered?
canvas.example: Tesla: create charging network, OTA updates

name: Jobs To Be Done (JTBD)
description: Understand the 'job' customers hire the product to do

framework.template: When [SITUATION], I want to [MOTIVATION], so I can [EXPECTED OUTCOME]
examples: When [waiting for the bus], I want to [pass time productively], so I can [feel like I didn't waste time] → TikTok, Duolingo
When [sending money to a friend], I want to [do it instantly for free], so I can [avoid going to the bank] → MoMo, ZaloPay
When [learning to code], I want to [practice in browser], so I can [skip complex IDE setup] → Replit, CodeSandbox

job_types.desc: How they want to be perceived

name: Value Proposition Canvas
description: Map customer profile to value proposition

customer_profile.prompt: What jobs are customers trying to get done?
Pains, risks, obstacles related to jobs?

value_map.prompt: How do you relieve their pains?

name: Design Sprint (Google Ventures)
description: 5-day process for answering critical business questions through design, prototyping, and testing

name: SWOT Analysis
description: Analyze 4 aspects: Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats

name: Crazy 8s
description: Sketch 8 ideas in 8 minutes — speed over perfection

name: First Principles Thinking
description: Break problems down to basic truths and rebuild from there

steps.prompt: Break down the problem to its fundamental truths.
Rebuild the solution from scratch without assumptions.

examples.first_principle: Batteries = raw materials (metal + chemicals) → buy materials + manufacture in-house
Humans learn by doing → provide immediate coding environment, explain later

name: Six Thinking Hats
description: 6 different perspectives to evaluate any idea or decision comprehensively

hats.question: What do we know? What data do we need?
What's your gut feeling? What excites or worries you?
hats.example: This feels like it could be huge, but the timing worries me

hats.question: What could go wrong? What are the dangers?
hats.example: Competitors have 10x our budget. Regulation could kill us.

hats.question: What's the best case? What opportunities exist?
hats.example: If we get 1% of the market, that's $42M ARR

hats.question: What new ideas can we generate? What if we did it differently?
hats.example: What if we flip the business model and make the tool free?

hats.question: What's our next step? How do we organize this thinking?
hats.example: Let's test this with 50 users in 2 weeks before committing

name: Reverse Brainstorming
description: Instead of solving the problem, brainstorm ways to CAUSE or WORSEN it — then reverse those ideas into solutions

steps.prompt: How could we make this problem WORSE?
steps.example: How to make onboarding MORE confusing?

steps.prompt: List 10+ ways to cause or worsen the problem.
steps.example: Add 20 form fields, use jargon, hide the skip button

steps.prompt: Flip each bad idea into a positive solution.
steps.example: → 2 fields max, plain language, prominent skip button

steps.prompt: Which reversed ideas are most impactful and feasible?

name: TRIZ (40 Inventive Principles)
description: Systematic innovation method — identify contradictions and apply proven inventive principles to resolve them

key_principles.name: Segmentation
key_principles.description: Divide an object or system into independent parts

key_principles.name: Taking out / Extraction
key_principles.description: Remove a problematic part or extract the useful part
key_principles.example: Noise-canceling headphones extract and invert ambient noise

key_principles.name: Prior Action
key_principles.description: Perform the required action in advance (pre-compute, pre-load)
key_principles.example: CDN pre-caches content. Apps pre-download for offline use.

key_principles.name: The Other Way Round / Inversion
key_principles.description: Invert the action or make the moving part fixed (and vice versa)
key_principles.example: Instead of user going to store → store comes to user (delivery apps)

key_principles.name: Dynamism
key_principles.description: Make an object or process adaptive, flexible, or adjustable
key_principles.example: Dynamic pricing, adaptive difficulty in games, responsive design

key_principles.name: Self-Service
key_principles.description: Make the object serve itself — perform supplementary functions automatically

key_principles.name: Replace Mechanical System
key_principles.description: Replace mechanical interaction with sensory, digital, or AI-based systems
key_principles.example: Physical key → biometric login. Manual moderating → AI moderation.

key_principles.name: Parameter Change
key_principles.description: Change an object's physical or digital state (format, interface, model)
key_principles.example: Newspaper → digital news. Desktop software → SaaS.

best_for: Resolving trade-offs (speed vs quality, cost vs features)

name: Disney Creative Strategy
description: Walt Disney's 3-room method: Dream → Plan → Critique. Each role thinks separately to avoid killing ideas too early.

rooms.question: If there were NO limitations — budget, time, technology — what would we build?
rooms.output: Wild vision, ambitious features, blue-sky ideas
rooms.example: A personal AI tutor that adapts to your mood and teaches through games

rooms.mindset: How do we actually build this?
rooms.question: What's the MVP? What resources do we need? What's the timeline?
rooms.output: Concrete plan, tech stack, milestones, resource requirements
rooms.example: Phase 1: quiz app with GPT-4 backend. Phase 2: mood detection via camera. Budget: $5K.

rooms.mindset: What will go wrong? What are we missing?
rooms.question: What are the weaknesses? What would competitors do? What would make users leave?
rooms.output: Risk list, potential failures, competitive threats, mitigation strategies
rooms.example: Risk: GPT API costs at scale. Mitigation: cache common responses, use smaller model for simple tasks.

process: Cycle through all 3 rooms multiple times until the idea is refined.
best_for: Solo brainstorming when you need multiple perspectives

name: 10x Moonshot Thinking
description: Don't improve by 10% — improve by 10X. Forces radical rethinking of the problem and solution space.

steps.prompt: What does the current solution look like? What are its limitations?
steps.example: Current: Users manually track expenses in spreadsheets

steps.prompt: What would a 10X BETTER solution look like? (Not incremental — transformational)
steps.example: 10x: AI reads all your bank transactions, categorizes automatically, predicts future spend, suggests savings

steps.prompt: What technology or capability is needed to close the gap between 1x and 10x?
steps.example: Need: Open Banking API + ML categorization + predictive model

steps.prompt: What's the realistic 3x that moves toward the 10x vision?
steps.example: 3x: Connect bank API → auto-categorize → monthly report. (Build toward prediction later)

examples.moonshot_10x: AI tutor that adapts in real-time to your learning style, pace, and mistakes

examples.current_1x: Search → browse → add to cart → checkout
examples.moonshot_10x: AI personal shopper that knows your style, budget, and needs — auto-curates

examples.current_1x: Call clinic → wait → book appointment → wait more
examples.moonshot_10x: AI triage that diagnoses, prescribes, and dispatches care within minutes
examples.stepping_stone_3x: Symptom checker → instant video call with doctor → e-prescription
